comment._content: NYT of Feb 6, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03EFD6143EE033A... in column 4 includes a piece on the newly opened Varick House, a modern hotel for working women. The sewing room is mentioned. Also part of the 6-storey 8-room facility were a gymnasium with running track and a yard and basketball court.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The boarding house, located in the heart of what was then the factory district, was intended to provide wholesome, home-like lodging for "factory girls". It was built in memory of the Spring Street Presbyterian Church's late pastor in a charitable effort led by Wm. Sloane Coffin (wealthy father of theologian Wm. Sloane Coffin, Jr,) ., and two others.. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F2091EF73F5A15738... . By the late 20's it was an NYU men's dormitory. In 1937, it became the Salvation Army's Evangeline House, providing housing again for women of limited means, and later its Women's Lodge. It was demolished in the mid-70's. The Trump SoHo tower now stands on the site. wirednewyork.com/forum/showthread.php?t=8466&page=50 The Spring Street church, now demolished also , was part of the same block, north of Varick House. The Trump SoHo tower covers the entire block formerly occupied by the church and its affiliated buildings.
